Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to discover revolutionary origami-based electromagnetic components, radiofrequency circuits, and systems, that will transform the fields of communications, energy autonomy and sensing. This research is producing the first origami engineered systems with cognitive capabilities, that are exploitating numerous bands of the ambient radiation spectrum. The scientific objective of this work is to derive rigorous and integrated Mathematical-Computational-Electromagnetic models of origami geometries in order to study and develop novel foldable, energy autonomous and self-deployable electromagnetic systems with multi-band and folding-dependent operation. This comprehensive, fundamental study of origami foldable and self-deployable electromagnetic systems focuses on the development of advanced miniaturized, perpetual (that is, autonomous battery-less operation through energy harvesting and wireless power transfer) and reconfigurable electromagnetic systems for next generation communication, reconnaissance, sensing, as well as wireless power systems that support civilian and military applications.

If successful, this work will benefit the fields of autonomous near-zero-power reconfigurable wireless telecommunications and sensing systems operating in harsh environments, such as disaster areas, structural health monitoring, Internet-of-Things, agricultural and water quality monitoring. Also, this work is expected to revolutionize airborne and wearable antennas, antenna arrays, resonators, harvesters, radiofrequency circuits and Wireless Sensor Networks realized in a variety of flexible materials with an easy to launch and carry miniaturized folded area. The project will also bring benefits to autonomous radio frequency devices with enhanced electromagnetic compatibility capabilities that can be integrated with biomedical implants and biosensors. This will enhance our national capabilities for disease prevention and real-time treatment as well as improving health and quality of life. The project's educational efforts are focused on broadening participation of underrepresented groups in science, technology, engineering and mathematics through curriculum development, undergraduate research experiences and outreach efforts. Broad dissemination of the project results will be accomplished through presentations to schools and the industrial community.

This project is jointly funded by the National Science Foundation and the US Air Force Office of Scientific Research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Summary: This research derived novel origami-based electromagnetic (EM) systems that are expected to transform the fields of communications, autonomy, and sensing. We developed the first origami engineered systems with unprecedented capabilities of reconfigurability, deployability and packability. The scientific objective of this collaborative research between Georgia Tech and FIU was accomplished by deriving integrated Mathematical-Computational-ElectroMagnetic (MCEM) models of novel foldable origami electromagnetic systems with multi-band and folding-dependent operation. We achieved our objective by completing comprehensive, fundamental studies of origami foldable and self-deployable EM systems and focusing our research on critical issues for the development of such systems. Our research outcomes are expected to significantly impact next generation communication, reconnaissance, and sensing systems by providing a solid foundation for understanding and designing origami antennas.

 

Intellectual Merit: Our proposed research was creative and original, because it generated the required fundamental and technological knowledge for bridging the challenges of engineering electromagnetics and mathematical/computational design by incorporating mechanical and electrical material properties into origami designs in order to realize novel origami-based EM systems. Therefore, our research outcomes are expected to have significant impact on the development of novel origami foldable and self-deployable EM systems based on: (a) rigorous and integrated MCEM 2D/3D models of origami EM systems, (b) the in-depth MCEM understanding, formulation, and optimization of origami flat, rigid and semi-rigid topologies, (c) the discovery of optimal miniaturization methodologies through origami, (d) the characterization of the folding-dependent performance of origami EM systems across different folding scales, and (e) discovery of novel origami EM systems, such as, antennas, frequency selective surfaces, and arrays with capabilities of miniaturization, deployability, reconfiguration, tunability, and multi-functionality.

 

Broader Impact: The work, our interdisciplinary research team produced, is expected to yield significant societal benefits because of its U.S. and global impact to vital national civilian and military needs in the fields of autonomous reconfigurable wireless telecommunications and sensing systems operating in harsh environments (e.g., disaster-hit areas, structural health monitoring, agricultural/food and water quality monitoring). Also, our work is expected to revolutionize spaceborne, airborne and wearable antennas, which are realized in a variety of flexible materials. Our educational efforts focused on broadening participation of underrepresented groups in STEM through curriculum development, REU/REM programs, and outreach efforts to support critical societal and defense needs.

 

Research Outcomes: Our research in this NSF project pioneered the development of origami antennas and origami electromagnetics by providing a solid foundation for understanding and designing robust physically reconfigurable and packable multifunctional antennas. Specifically, we introduced: (a) physically reconfigurable antennas that can change their frequency of operation, radiation pattern, and polarization, (b) active deployable and reconfigurable arrays and MIMO systems, (c) passive deployable arrays with superior electromagnetic performance, (d) origami frequency selective surfaces that transform electromagnetic waves, (e) novel fabrication techniques for foldable antennas using multi-layer and multi-material structures, and (f) novel metallizations for self-morphing electronics. Our antennas can be built with flexible and rigid materials and can be stowed with very high packing efficiencies, thereby providing transformative capabilities in terms of packability, deployability, and reconfigurability. Therefore, our origami-inspired antenna technologies can be incorporated in many applications, such as: (a) space systems, since origami antennas can be compactly stowed during launch and then deployed to large apertures when they reach orbit, and (b) battlefield systems, since origami antennas can reduce the size and weight of communication equipment that soldiers carry.
